content: I used the testcases as training data to make my NN work and calculate weights. I think it would be nice to put training data as part of the puzzle that could be used with a NN.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I removed the noise and tried circle, then square, then triangle.
Good job
You could make noise in the background art a different color from the corresponding shape, to aid in its visual interpretation.

I hacked together an algorithm that was able to pass all the test cases, but failed on two of the validators. Now, I could just tweak my code, since I'm able to see the validators after all, but that wouldn't really be fair. And anyway it doesn't seem like any small tweaks suffice. Admittedly my approach isn't the way it was intended to be solved, but I don't think it's wrong to think outside the box. For sure it would drive me mad trying to figure out what I did wrong. If it's likely that a neural net might also have trouble distinguishing squares from circles, then I'd suggest using maybe a star shape or a donut instead. I'd at least be more comfortable if there's some investigation into how difficult it is to get stuck the way I am. Because situations like these, if they're common enough, can really penalize the rating of a puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because it presents a clean, interpretable task rooted in geometry and suited for creative classification techniques.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i used erode to reduce noise and coefficient of variation over distances from center of mass to borders to classify the geometric shape.... i think that is a good approach.... i couldn't do it the first try... because the erode has conflicts when the polygon touch the border of the grid.... but managing the border value correctly it works oke.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I wonder if it might look a little nicer to have a gradient with maybe 5 to 10 different characters or numeric values. In that case the background and foreground shades don't have to be at the extremes.

Goal
* Please change "representing" to "showing".

* Please change "an peudo-random" to "a pseudo-random" (both words should be changed).

* Please add "with {{#}}" after "filled".

Input
* Please change "seperated" to "separated".

Constraints/Cases
* You may remove some of the constraints as they repeat what has already been stated in Goal section. However, if you do decide to keep the constraints here, please change "may be" to "is" in the last constraint.

* Are some of the shapes cut off at the edges of the 20x20 grid? For example, the square in "10% Accuracy" test look that way to me.

  • If that shouldn't be the case, please amend any such cases accordingly, and add a constraint stating that all shapes are drawn in full within the 20x20 grid.
  
  • Otherwise, please mention in Goal section that the shape may be cut off slightly at the edges of the 20x20 grid.

Cases
* What do the accuracy percentages in the names of the cases refer to?

Stub generator
* Please change Line 1 to:
loop 20 loopline 20 filled:word(1)

(You may also change "filled" to another variable name.)

Thanks.
Thanks for your feedback! Fixed all the issues.

That could be a great idea, but I prefer its current simplicity: just a simple bitwise map. I can't rewrite the entire puzzle from scratch and solve it just to add a simple feature, but I'll keep that in mind for future puzzles. Thanks anyways!

Thanks for the approval!

In my solution, I used DFS to select the biggest shape in size, so all the small unattached pixels were removed, and then a simple neural network helped with the classification.
Thanks for your approval, I appreciate it a lot!!
Thanks for the approval!

Did using the test cases only as a training database solve the puzzle? That's cool! I didn't expect that.

I thought about including a link to a GitHub database, but then I thought reverse engineering the shape generation process would be cool too. You could create a simple program that generates shapes with different sizes, then add noise (or not, in case you manually remove noise using convolution or BFS). And then use it to train your NN.
How did that happen? I personally didn’t change anything since the contribution was published.

I don't know who did it or exactly when. However, there've been a few incidents earlier this year where puzzles were modified by users other than the original authors. Anyone with a high enough level can make changes.
How did you notice changes have been made? Do you receive any notifications as a moderator?
No, there aren't any notifications, even as a moderator. I keep some sort of database myself and check regularly.

That's some amazing and serious dedication from you!

Just curious if Codingame re-runs all the submitted solutions once a validator changes. Or are all users who had solved the puzzle still considered to have solved it, even if their code would fail on the updated validator?
It's the latter situation. There aren't any re-runs.
On the other hand, this attempt was so feeble, maybe it should have failed. I just don't like that it failed on only validators.

your elimination while loop looks awesome... but it leaves some rubbish cells like in 50% Accuracy test... but it seems like it doesn't affect the validators you are pointing at..... i didn't knew the math.tau constant on your code... looks nice.... also... i think your approach is to determine the change of angles from the center of mass to all cells of the figure? i am not sure... what is your approach? is something related that the triangle has 3 symmetry lines, the square 8 and circle infinity?

I think this problem can't be solved easily, since any probabilistic model might fail on a validator but pass all tests. It is a problem that I faced too while working on the problem, and all I could do was tweak my code to increase its accuracy.

Your code is actually very good. I'm impressed that you managed to distinguish between the shapes without using a probabilistic model like neural nets. I think what you should try to do to pass those validators is maybe extract more features from the shapes. The more features you have, the better the accuracy. Try to think of a new feature that would help distinguish squares from circles, since they do indeed look kind of similar sometimes.

From the center of mass, determine distance to the edge as you go around the circle, and try to find some symmetry in that, yes. Often circles resemble octagons so have 4-symmetry above noise level. I'm going to have to find the corners of a shape to confirm it's actually square.

ooh... that's why the DATA SCIENTIST name on the test cases!!!.... i had never used neural network by raw.... always using keras, tensorflow or some predefined machine learning models... it's good to see that here
Yeah .... it's actually quite a good exercise to try to recreate a neural network class from scratch without using libraries. It makes you understand better the math behind them.
No problem. May I know what the accuracy percentages in the names of the cases refer to?
The percentages don’t actually mean anything except to encourage the coder to improve their prediction accuracy, they’re just a fun way of naming the test cases.
